The period before recorded history is known as prehistory. This era spans from the emergence of the first humans to the invention of writing. During prehistory, societies developed complex systems of government, economy, and culture. People built structures such as the Pyramids of Giza and Stonehenge, and developed tools and technologies that helped them adapt to their environments. The end of prehistory marked the beginning of recorded history, when people started writing down their stories, laws, and events. This transition occurred around 5,200 years ago, with the invention of writing in Mesopotamia. The study of prehistory is essential to understanding human evolution, culture, and the development of civilizations. By examining artifacts, fossils, and other evidence, archaeologists and historians can reconstruct the lives of people who lived before recorded history. Their findings provide valuable insights into the past, allowing us to better comprehend the complexities of human societies and the impact of environmental factors on their development. In

Prehistory started millions of years ago and ended with the invention of writing, which was different in various cultures.
